awd_titl_txt: Robert Noyce Scholarship Program for Science and Mathematics Teachers

por.por_cntn:
The Robert Noyce Scholarship Program for Science and Mathematics Teachers (DUE 1035483) was initiated with the goal to certify science and mathematics teachers highly qualified to teach in our partner Dallas, Arlington, and Fort Worth Independent School Districts. The program has been a collaborative effort among the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), College of Education (COEd) and College of Science (COS), Tarrant County Community College District (TCCD), and our partner and other surrounding high need school districts. The program supports the preparation of secondary and middle level science and mathematics teachers through campus courses, online and face-to-face mentoring, and classroom teaching experiences in our UTeach Arlington and post-baccalaureate teacher certification programs. The program objectives were to:

  1. recruit mathematics and science teacher candidates from baccalaureate programs and career changers from local industry,
  2. provide a quality two-track teacher certification program for our candidates
  3. induct, monitor, and mentor our teacher candidates through the program and their early years of teaching

The US currently faces a critical need for qualified science and mathematics teachers, with shortages most severe in in high-poverty urban and rural districts. Texas is experiencing profound teacher shortages, with science and mathematics reported by the Texas Education Agency as needing more teachers than any other field. The Dallas-Fort Worth (DFW) area is the 4th largest metropolitan area in the country, with its three largest school districts, Dallas, Fort Worth, and Arlington enrolling nearly 309,000 students, and with all three designated as economically disadvantaged school districts. The University of Texas at Arlington is well positioned for the work of this program, being a large, Hispanic-Serving research institution (HSI) situated at the center of the DFW Metroplex. Most of students at UTA in general, but specifically those who earn Noyce Scholarships and become teachers attended K-12 schools in the DFW area. Thus, this UTA Noyce program responded to the severe math and science teacher shortages in DFW by preparing a cadre of new science and mathematics teachers prepared for teaching in high need schools, with most returning to teach in school districts like those from which they graduated.  

The UTA Noyce program exceeded the originally proposed number of Noyce Scholars to be supported (54) and Summer Internships awarded (50), by funding 68 Noyce Scholars and awarding 60 Summer Internships. Noyce Scholars earned $10,000 scholarships for up to 2 years toward teacher certification (undergraduates) or for one year (post-baccalaureates). Summer Internships were awarded to freshman and sophomore students to work with partner STEM and STEM education agencies, such as the science museums and nature centers, for five weeks (200 hours) in the summer as a recruitment initiative.

Throughout their teacher education program, candidates were engaged in learning and gaining skill in implementing research-based inquiry teaching models, project- and problem-based instruction, and classroom research, with significant time and teaching in various K-12 classrooms throughout the program. The program also engaged teacher candidates in developing and sharing curricula, teaching in high need schools, discussing field experiences, and reflecting on their teaching practices. Additional professional development was provided to Noyce Scholars through Scholar Learning Seminars, electronic communication and media, and professional meetings and conferences. Noyce Scholars were also provided significant and consistent guidance and mentoring via interactions with the PI/Co-PI team members, the Noyce Scholar Leader, faculty content and pedagogy mentors, and school-based Mentor Teachers.

The Intellectual Merit includes the direct contribution to the body of research, teacher education, and curriculum development that were the hallmarks of this project. Data collected through our research program indicated Noyce Scholars experienced positive shifts in self-efficacy toward teaching science and mathematics, and shifted from didactic to more inquiry-based teaching through the program. The program and research from this Noyce Program has been disseminated through presentations at numerous professional conferences and publications, with more research to be analyzed and manuscripts published in the coming years. Intellectual merit is further exemplified by Noyce Scholars gaining skills and knowledge and contributing to their profession with new teaching skills/strategies and pedagogical content knowledge in mathematics and science for urban students in high-need schools. Our Noyce Scholars are engaged in professional organizations, have taken leaderships roles in their schools and districts, and  continue to present their own research and teaching practices through publication and professional presentations as teacher-leaders in their fields.

Through this program, 91% of teacher certified Noyce scholars are currently teaching or have taught in a high need district, with 86% currently teaching in a high need district. The Broader Impacts of this program include over 10,000 students in high need schools per year are being taught science and mathematics by highly qualified teachers in the field. These students directly benefit from having teachers who hold deep understandings of the content and how to best teach that content to diverse students in high-need schools.


Last Modified: 02/28/2018
Modified by: Ann L Cavallo
